review_text: This has to be the best pair of sub-$100 earbuds I have ever used. They are comfortable and sound great like actually sound great! The fit perfectly in my ears and don‚Äôt create any pressure with such an amazing pass through mode. Would highly recommend for listening to music or using with a portable gaming device!

product: Baseus Inspire XC1 Open Ear Clip-On Earbuds
review_text: As a previous owner the Baseus MC1 Pro, I already had high expectations for the XC1.The MC1 Pro sounded great and was very comfortable to wear. Unfortunately I lost them by accident.Having experienced the quality of the Baseus sound product, I had good feelings about purchasing the higher tier XC1.The XC1 certainly did not disappoint. Right out of the box, you can feel that the build quality and design are one step above the MC1 Pro. It absolutely feel like a premium product just by holding them in your hand.The Bose calibrated sound is also a step up from the MC2 Pro, with more pronounced bass and better clarity. The max volume is also higher which helps in noisy environments. The additional EQ presets from the app are also very useful.You get the same level of comfort wearing them - they are so light that you sometimes can't even feel them on your ears. The battery last forever and even when you run out, it takes just a few minutes in the case to recharge enough for a few more hours.Overall, this is an amazing product. For the build quality, sound quality, style and comfort, it is almost impossible to beat in this price range.

product: Baseus Inspire XC1 Open Ear Clip-On Earbuds
review_text: Ok, so this review is specifically for using these while running because that is the sole purpose that I purchased them for and all of my insights will relate to that.Let me start with all of the good things about these:1) They sound really good. In comparison to other open ear designs I have tried I would easily put these in the top 3. Bass response is good at most volumes. Clarity is very good and the imaging is surprisingly amazing. Vocal sound like they are in the center of my head. Very impressive for open ear design2) Volume is sufficient. These go loud enough to hear over traffic without any distortion and minimal loss of fidelity. Please keep in mind that there is a level of volume that is loud enough to negate the need for open ear at all. I mean, if it's blasting so loud that you can't hear sounds around you then maybe open ear is not the style for you3) comfort. These feel great. They are extremely light and even when they move around you don't even notice it. I have taken these on runs as long as 13 miles from easy days all the way up to advanced speed work and have had no issues with them shifting or falling off. They do not fit quite as tight as i had expected which seemed like it would be an issue, but surprisingly it was not a problem4) customization. This one is a mixed bag, but mostly good. The app gives you plenty of options to tweak the sound quality and customize the buttons. The only thing it won't let you do is change the single tap function. This isn't a deal breaker and i am guessing it has to do with a hard coded part of the firmware, but it would be nice to have a single tap function that is different on each head phone.So here are the things i think they could improve on:1) The buttons are a little mushy so they can be a little difficult to press and sometimes a little difficult if you are trying to double press or press and hold. I prefer a more "clicky" button that has some physical feedback when you press it. Or even if the buttons stuck out just a little bit more. When you are running fast and your hands are sweaty it can be a little bit of a challenge. Having said that, they are still way ahead of touch controls when you have sweaty hands2) no feedback on button presses. Most headphones have a simple "beep" when you press the button so you can tell that the headphones have received your input. This is useful when your devices take a second or two to respond. They beep when a bluetooth connection is made so I know the capability exists. This could be something they could add with a firmware/app update I am sure, and it would be nice to have3) no "in field" pairing. This set like many others, require the case to be present in order to pair them with your device. I have found a few that will let you pair them without the case and to me that is a HUGE benefit. It's not a deal breaker but that is something i would love to have and would even pay a few dollars more forBattery life so far has been about as expected which is roughly 20% per hour at 75% volume. Not "Best in class" but should be more than enough for most people to use for the dayOverall, i have tried a lot of different brands and models and they all have flaws and they all cost a lot more than these (sometimes upwards of twice the cost) and these have none of those flaws so far.I was hesitant to try a cheaper set from a brand i am not familiar with but i am glad that i did because these are my new daily use headphones when i run.

product: Baseus Inspire XC1 Open Ear Clip-On Earbuds
review_text: Baseus really hit a homerun with these. I was a little skeptical at first just from the clip on design itself and the fact that most clipons ive tried have left me feeling disappointed. But these are an absolute MUST buy for anyone looking for a clip on.The sound is awesome, at low volume (30% or so) they do a great job of still being clearly audible and having a bass that is still present. Once you crank it up to 70-80 they definitely pump out some nice sound. Top that off with the nice soft rubber grips and a sturdy fit you have yourself not only a comfortable earbud but a great WORKOUT earbud.The battery life is good as well, i went a whole session with volume at about 60% and got almost 9 hours from them which is insane. The button on each earbud can be customized with many options to choose from which is nice too. I haven't necessarily used them for calls specifically but ended up using them on a discord call and got zero complaints so i assume they must be fine as well.Overall these are easy to recommend for anyone interested in clip ons and especially as a gift option.

product: Baseus Inspire XC1 Open Ear Clip-On Earbuds
review_text: Works well. Removed one star because they are loose on my ear. Still a strong 4 stars because minimal audio leakage, good sound, otherwise comfortable to wear.Good product for anyone who finds earbuds uncomfortable as i do.

product: Baseus Inspire XC1 Open Ear Clip-On Earbuds
review_text: I just purchased these Baseus open ear buds to replace my old Jlab ones. So far they are great. I primarily use them for music listening while still being able to pick up outside sounds and keep mobile. The Bose bass sounds excellent with no distortion. They are lightweight and comfortable with thoughtful little rubber nubs where they come in contact with your ears. Buttons work fine. I personally like the open ear ring type buds. They look like some kind of cyber-tribal piercing thing, which works for me. I still wish they‚Äôd invent an accessory miniature subwoofer that clips into your nostrils through.Update 12/25: After a couple of months I‚Äôm still liken‚Äô these ear bud. My only issues are the little control buttons. The ‚Äòfeel‚Äô of the buttons when pressed doesn‚Äôt do it for me. It‚Äôs hard to tell when you‚Äôre activating a command. I have a feeling these will not last  in prolonged use. Also the buttons would be better bigger and maybe knurled rubber caps for easier use. I should also mention that the charger case is horrible. It‚Äôs larger than the cheaper Jlab one that this replaced and very, very difficult to open. It needs a recessed finger groove or something.

product: Baseus Bowie MC1 Open Ear Clip-On Earbuds
review_text: I use these all the time. The open ear design means I can hear my surroundings and the audio coming from the earbuds perfectly. I am an equestrian and use these with my coach so I can hear her better in crowded environments like at shows or windy days. They stay on great and never had them slip or move while I was riding or running. I recently lost the case at the airport and e-mailed the company to see if I could just buy the case since I still had the earbuds. They were kind enough to send me a new set! Not only are these earbuds fantastic quality and a great price but the customer service is top notch and quick to respond.

product: Baseus Bowie MC1 Open Ear Clip-On Earbuds
review_text: I really prefer open-earbuds to in-earbuds, cuz after I got some foam tips for better comfort - my ears still get "swamp ear" and get irritated after long use. So I bought Bose Ultra open buds and Shokz open fit buds. Usually I say they are good for what it‚Äôs worth. In this case, for what I paid for them, they are not worth it. I finally decided to see if there was a better alternative and stumbled upon these Baseus Bowie MC1 clip earbuds, which seemed like they could be the answer.‚ù§üß°üíõüíöüíôüíúPro‚Äôs:The fit is excellent, the sound is excellent, the ear clip/cuff design is different and good, the fit is pretty secure and won‚Äôt fall off, comfortable. When running I hardly noticed I had them on my ears. The sound was good when I was running.The Shokz are really good and probably rank them as one of the best hook buds in the market. For me and my ears, the Baseus is an excellent buy. These are light and fitment is excellent, the sound is superb, the call quality I give to Shokz, the update happened to both and somehow the call quality on the Baseus really improved. I still prefer the physical button over the touch sensitive approach that Shokz went with. I still like the Baseus ear clip design vs the earhook. So which do I prefer. Running and exercising-Baseus without a doubt.Bose Ultra is too expensive, can‚Äôt adjust to being closer to ear canal, left me wanting and expecting more from the ear cuff buds. They seem limited when turning them up to 7 or 8 on the flat setting. Should be priced around the Soundcore and Shokz open fit buds price, maybe even pricing them lower like $125-$150 on the high end. For $300 they should have wireless charging, multi point connectivity. Most of all a larger and louder volume level. I‚Äôm returning them. My Baseus Bowie MC1 do a better job and lasts my whole 10 hour workday without needing to be charged. These are a great option for an open-ear design at this price point, the sound is very full and balanced, impressive bass and volume without becoming distorted, I rarely feel the need to turn them up too much even when in a noisy area.‚ù§üß°üíõüíöüíôüíúWhat I liked:‚ù§1) Very comfortable, light weight, you will not even know that you are wearing itüß°2) Easy to put on and remove and just one clicker on the back of the ear on each earbud to control settings like volume, play next or previous track, take a call or end it or cycle through the modes (default list of modes can be assigned to each earbud so that you can cycle through the shortcuts you use the most).üíõ3) Pushing it downwards inside the ear gives a higher bass and louder sound. My ears are small so this could be different for different ear sizes. The sound quality is premium and you can move it a bit to find the right spot for best sound.üíö4) Call quality is good. I did not face any issues during the call while I was walking outsideüíô6) You can hear the surroundings while outside, although some level of noise is reduced so that you enjoy the music.üíú7) Baseus app enables you to: pair the device with your phone, calibrating the earbuds so that you get good sound quality, selecting the equalizer (bass, mid-range, treble) is available.‚ù§8) The charging case is small and pocketable with good battery life. Up to 9-10 hours of play time and up to an extra 31 hours of battery life in the charging case.

product: Baseus Bowie MC1 Open Ear Clip-On Earbuds
review_text: I bought these as a second round choice to some JBL earpods I initially purchased and ended up returning immediately.The JBL earpods would not consistently stay in my ear no matter the provided ear adapter I tried.I was originally hesitant about buying these "clip-on" style ones as a replacement.But after trying them out I was extremely satisfied.They are super lightweight, comfortable, and STAY in place no matter how hard I seem to move or shake my head.I have worn them doing sweaty rough yardwork with no issues at all.Sound/volume might vary a tiny bit depending where the speaker sits in your ear once clipped on.And like all earpods, you don't get the same bass as over-ear headphones...However I think these have all around good sound and listen to rock/metal, EDM, rap, podcasts, etc on them.Charging is quick and easy.Connection/pairing seems to work extremely well and is very seamless placing in/out of the case.Range seems comparable to larger headphones.I would give them 4 1/2 stars, knocking half a star off for better bass (if possible in such a compact package).

product: Baseus Bowie MC1 Open Ear Clip-On Earbuds
review_text: I have tried so many earbuds, but they always fall out of my ears. I bought some other cheaper out of ear headphones, but they were garbage. These are fantastic! They stay on, I hear great through them, they hold a charge a really long time (probably about 8 hours of straight use) and the case holds a charge for about a week. They are lightweight and comfortable. A little bit of trouble with phone calls sometimes, but other times it‚Äôs fine, so it could be another issue. I love them so much!!!

product: Baseus Bowie MC1 Open Ear Clip-On Earbuds
review_text: These earbuds are great. These are the best earbuds that I have found. I like that it doesn‚Äôt invade my ear and the sound it‚Äôs not compromised. It has really good sound quality, the battery is great, the design it‚Äôs cute. The only thing i don‚Äôt like the size it‚Äôs a bit big for my ear but they are great and comfortable. It‚Äôs easy to connect and the weight it‚Äôs light.

product: Baseus Bowie MC1 Open Ear Clip-On Earbuds
review_text: First of all, I really love this open ear earbuds.  They are very comfortable, loose but still secure.  Sound is good enough, including some level of bass. Build quality is good too.  Overall I really like them and plan to keep them.HOWEVER, after a week of use, I realize the ear buds mic will stop working either when I walk away from my laptop like going to bathroom or kitchen.  It seems the disconnection is random to me.  I am not sure it's because of distance or period of not streaming.  But the worst is the mic will not work properly even the earbuds reconnect with my laptop.  I HAVE to unpair and repair the earbuds with my laptop.  As I use this earbuds for work from home meetings, this random disconnection / malfunction of mic is such a pain that finally I decided to return the earbuds.  It is such a shame.  I did see one another user commented the same issue but I thought that was random.  But in my case, it happens pretty much everyday.... so if you want to use this earbuds for meetings, be careful.  Otherwise this earbuds is almost perfect for me.

product: Baseus Bowie MC1 Pro Open Ear Earbuds
review_text: These earbuds are super comfortable and feel almost weightless. I love the open-ear design ‚Äî I can still hear what‚Äôs happening around me while getting clear, punchy sound. The bass is surprisingly good for this style, and the calls sound very clear. Battery life is solid and they‚Äôre great for workouts. Definitely worth it!

product: Baseus Bowie MC1 Pro Open Ear Earbuds
review_text: I‚Äôm really impressed with the Baseus Bowie MC1 Pro. The open-ear design is extremely comfortable‚Äîperfect for long listening sessions without any pressure on the ears. The audio is surprisingly clear and well-balanced, with a natural sound that makes music and podcasts enjoyable.I also love how they keep me aware of my surroundings while still delivering great audio quality. The battery life is solid, and the Bluetooth connection is stable with no interruptions.Lightweight, comfortable, and very practical‚Äîthese headphones exceeded my expectations. Highly recommended for everyday use, workouts, or working on the go!

product: Baseus Bowie MC1 Pro Open Ear Earbuds
review_text: Really comfy! With the clip-on design and soft silicone padding, I hardly notice I‚Äôm wearing them, even on long runs. The sound is solid for open-ear earbuds: midrange and vocals feel clear, though there‚Äôs no earth-shattering bass. For running, they‚Äôre actually great, super lightweight, stay in place, and let you hear your surroundings, which is perfect for safety.The IP67 rating also gives me confidence when I sweat or run in light rain.Bottom line: Highly recommended if comfort and awareness are your priorities. Not for bass lovers, but for running or day-long wear, these are a winner.

product: Baseus Bowie MC1 Pro Open Ear Earbuds
review_text: Awesome price and valve for these tariff ridden times. A very nice product w/ a wide range use and user friendly. Noise cancellation was not very effective but it hard to turn everything out. Sounds great, looks sleek, functions well minus 150$ for others needsüëç

product: Baseus Bowie MC1 Pro Open Ear Earbuds
review_text: I really like the design, because the U-shape, similar to an earring, makes them very hard to fall out while wearing.The high-resolution sound  is very clear and detailed, almost like listening to an original CD. SuperBass 2.0 is a feature that makes the bass deeper and more powerful, while the high notes stay clear and crisp.The 4 microphones with AI technology for calls makes there‚Äôs noise around you, your voice will come through loud and clear to the person on the other end.They are also water-resistant , so there‚Äôs no problem using them in the rain or while sweating during exercise. They are comfortable, fit well in the ear, and can be worn for long periods without discomfort. Overall, they offer great sound, comfort, and durability in a stylish and secure design.

product: Baseus Bowie MC1 Pro Open Ear Earbuds
review_text: I really like these earbuds. I tried other earbuds in bestbuy, and decided I'd rather not waste hundreds of dollars on a wireless earbud set. I am a huge fan of brands that offer their customers high quality items without having a huge price tag, and I respect these brands as long as they keep pumping out high quality items.These earbuds are extremely loud, the sound is 10/10, it feels like I'm listening out of a high quality stereo speaker phone that is in my ear. I love that these DO NOT have touch control, because it makes it easier to use during rain or shower, which I did do today. I wore these in the shower and the sound remained 10/10, something that no other earbud I ever owned was able to achieve. No muffled sound, no loss in quality, absolutely amazing in water.Also, the bass is pretty useless in this, but it doesnt matter too much because the sound quality makes up for it 100 percent.The battery life is good, I've been wearing them all day and they have a very premium build quality.The only thing I prefer, is more tighter or smaller rings, also I am unsure on how long the rubber parts will last. Other than these two worries, this is a 10/10 device and I am recommending them to everyone, and the app is so intuitive.

product: Baseus Bowie MC1 Pro Open Ear Earbuds
review_text: It is first time for me to use the open ear earbuds. It is so cool! Super easy of use and get connection to my phone. I would like to listen to music during work out, the old style earbuds are easy to get wet and slip out. But the function of this one is supper fit for exercise.The sound quality is just as good as in ear product. The price is very valuable for the good quality!

product: Baseus Bowie MC1 Pro Open Ear Earbuds
review_text: Disappointed. The sound quality is nominal--nothing spectacular--particularly the bass. Enhanced or not the bass is barely noticeable. The app gave it a little boost but if you are an audiophile and you want them for music, don't bother. The  FF/Next feature and the Previous feature do not work as tapping only results in Volume Control and Pause and Play regardless to the number of taps/beeps. I would surmise that although it is comfortable, it is not suited to all ear sizes because the "speaker" does not position itself in the same spot on every ear. For the price, I will be returning these.

product: Baseus Bowie 30 Max Active Noise Cancelling Headphones
review_text: Looking for the ultimate escape into your own world of sound? Look no further than the Baseus Bowie 30 Max Wireless Noise Cancelling Headphones. These sleek, over-the-ear headphones deliver unparalleled audio quality and immersive experiences, especially with the addition of Spatial Audio.üü•üüßüü®üü©üéßSoundüéßüü•üüßüü®üü©I own many pair of headphones, including AirPod Max, Sonos Ace, Bose QC 45, and the Sony XM5‚Äôs. I also owned and sold the QuietComfort Ultra, which are way overpriced. The Bowie 30 Max are quickly becoming my favorite. They sound better than all except the Apple AirPod Max. They are noticeably better than the QC 45. The bass is definitely deeper and punchier. The highs and mids are also discernibly better. The highs are brighter and more crisp. The 45‚Äôs require a lot of equalizer use, while the Bowie 30 Max still require some tinkering, they require a lot less of it to achieve optimum sound.üü•üüßüü®üü©üü¶üü™üü´üü•üüßüü®üü©üü¶üü™üéßSpatial Audio with Head Trackingüéßüü•üüßüü®üü©üü¶üü™üü´üü•üüßüü®üü©üü¶üü™What sets these headphones apart is their Spatial Audio feature, which takes your listening experience to the next level. Feel like you're right in the middle of the action, with sound that surrounds you in all directions, adding depth and dimension to your favorite content. I'll be honest, I thought that spatial audio may be more of a marketing gimmick, but it is incredible. Especially when watching movies, when you turn your head, the sound moves with you providing the feeling of being immersed in the moment. (Same as Bose QC Ultra, Airpods Max)üü•üüßüü®üü©üü¶üü™üü´üü•üéßNoise Cancellingüéßüü•üüßüü®üü©üü¶üü™üü´üü•I would say, at $99 ANC definetly worth the price. For the low-frequency noises, you know the annoying engine sound, it does the job same as Bose on airplanes! But for the higher frequency noises like people talking, I think it is above average, better than good but not Sony/Bose level. The one thing about the Bose/Sony is their ability to block ambient noise adaptively, but Bowie 30 Max only takes a 1/4 price of them, probably 1/5 with a coupon or a deal.üü•üüßüü®üü©üü¶üéßComfortüéßüü•üüßüü®üü©üü¶They are extremely lightweight (though sturdy), and clamp down perfectly tight. I can shake my head back and forth without them shifting, yet they‚Äôre not so tight as to prevent wearing them for an extended period of time. I don‚Äôt work out, but I would imagine they‚Äôd maintain their fit during exercise.üü•üüßüü®üü©üü¶üü™üéßBattery Lifeüéßüü•üüßüü®üü©üü¶üü™The battery life is super incredible and lasts like a full week if you were to use these all day everyday. I‚Äôve had these only like two weeks and I‚Äôve only charged it twice but I use these alot. I think I average about 3-4 hours a day wearing these during the week, and usually charge them once a week, but I don't let them get super low either. Charge super fast, 10 mins for 14 hours of use is just ridiculous.üü•üüßüü®üü©üü¶üü™üü´üü•üüßüü®üéßMulti-point Connectivityüéßüü•üüßüü®üü©üü¶üü™üü´üü•üüßüü®They also offer multi-point connectivity, and they (and the 45‚Äôs) are the only two pair to switch seamlessly between my LG TV and my iPhone. The XM5‚Äôs require using the app, the Sonos don‚Äôt do it as easily as advertised and the AirPods Max don‚Äôt even offer multipoint functionality.üéßIf you‚Äôre looking for your first pair, then I would definitely recommend the Bowie 30 Max over all the others I mentioned, even if they cost more than $99. I hope that helps. Happy Listening!üéß

product: Baseus Bowie 30 Max Active Noise Cancelling Headphones
review_text: The sound quality is truly remarkable for the price range. The noise cancelling and bluetooth are also impressive. You do have to set up the different profiles once in the app but from there it's fairly easy to use and quickly became my default headphone due to the comfortable fit and sound quality. This was remarkable to because I also have headsets which at 10-15x the price, so to say this is great value for money would be an understatement.The caveat - They've tried to give it a more high end aesthetic BUT the plastic used is still relatively brittle and did start to crack within 2 months. The earcups also started loosening. I've some experience fixing things so it's fine as a daily driver but I wouldn't wear these to the gym or on a flight in their current condition.Overall, great sound but it's got a life of ~6 months while I've headsets from Bose or Sennheiser that I've had for 3-5 years so you do get a much shorter life

product: Baseus Bowie 30 Max Active Noise Cancelling Headphones
review_text: I have listened to every kind of music genre with these, and I'm never fail to be blown away. The crispness of the instruments. The clarity of the voices. The thundering of the bass. The hair on my arms stands up. I have this test song that I use to grade clarity (don't laugh), Imperial March, Darth Vader's Theme. You can hear each instrument so clearly. You can pick each one out. On another song I listened to, I could even hear the pages being turned by the members of the orchestra, and you could hear the hair of the bow as it went across the bridge of the violin. Insane. Then I use Madman Across the Water by Elton John. You can hear each pick of the string on his guitar in the beginning. Go back and listen to You're So Vain by Carly Simon. I had NO IDEA that Mick Jagger sung the backup vocals. I could hear him belting out the words. I had to look it up to be sure because he's uncredited on the album. He was friends with her and he was just there the day she was recording and jumped in. Lastly, Head Like a Hole by Nine Inch Nails...it sounds like you're in the middle of a concert hall. You dont even have to have the spatial audio turned on for any of these songs, as the headphones are so good right out of the box, in Hi Fi live EQ mode. The ONLY thing I would change about them, is to make a fabric cushion on the headband, I stead of the pleather, because these suckers slide around if you move your head around too much. I tried laying down from a sitting down position, and the headphones made it to the pillow before I did. I'd still recommend them to anyone!!! The sound will blow your mind. Keep in mind, your sound experience is only as good as the quality of the music. The better it was mixed, the better it will sound. 70's music seems to have been more creatively, artistically and carefully mixed for some reason, and there are so many "easter eggs". The coolest feature about these is the on/off switch. You definitely know you've turned them off! The battery lasts forever! The light indicators on the outside of each cup are so helpful to let you know they're charging (blue) and when they're done (red). No guessing! Don't hesitate to buy these! Not at this price!Btw, they DO fold up, I just have a hard case.

product: Baseus Bass BC1 Open Ear Earbuds Clip-On Headphones
review_text: Took some time to get used to the feel of these as I've been using inner ear earbuds for years.  It was very easy to connect through bluetooth, the sound clarity on various tyes of music and podcasts are top notch.  I like that there are also specific buttons on the ear pieces so I can raise or lower volume, skip ahead, or take a call.  They're very comfortable and I don't get the constant usage itchiness from having something in my ear canal.  it clips onto my ear very easily with little broadcast "speakers" sitting outside my ear, they fit nicely and haven't moved to matter how much I may sweat.  i couldn't tell you the battery life yet but I've used them now for 3 days and as I take them out of the charging case they're still full of power.  The box says they're good for a totalk of 38 hours, if that isn't the case I'll edit my post, but it seems realisting.  At the sale price I got these for here on Amazon,. I'd say theis was an excellent value and the best purchase I've made this year so far. n

product: Baseus Bass BC1 Open Ear Earbuds Clip-On Headphones
review_text: These open-ear earbuds have been a great upgrade from traditional in-ear styles. They sit comfortably without pressing into the ear canal, so I can wear them for long periods without any pain or irritation. The open-ear design also makes it easy to stay aware of what‚Äôs going on around me while still getting clear, balanced sound.They‚Äôre lightweight, secure, and perfect for everyday use‚Äîwhether I‚Äôm walking, working, or listening to something at home. If regular earbuds tend to hurt your ears, these are a wonderful alternative that still deliver really good audio quality.

product: Baseus Bass BC1 Open Ear Earbuds Clip-On Headphones
review_text: These are currently my favorite headphones.  I'll highlight the pro's and few con's (because they are perfect) below...Pros:--Price.  I got these super cheap on sale (~$20).  From a quality and features standpoint, these headphones punch way above their class.--Super comfortable.  They are light but, more importantly, don't feel intrusive.  I love the open ear design.  Nothing is jammed in my ear resulting in zero fatigue, hot spots or swamp ear.  I have taken naps with them on (love being able to listen to music while napping).  Also, as someone who wears glasses, I love that there's no contact of any point between the headphones and glasses.  There's no feeling of pressure or the glasses sitting funny.--Physical buttons (especially at this price point).  I appreciate physical buttons over touch sensitivity.  It allows for precise execution of functions.-The accompanying app.  I think this feature separates these headphones from other low cost headphones.  I love that I'm able to select from different EQ setting to find one that best fits my tastes.  It can also be customized but my ears aren't that particular.  The ability to customize the button functions is also appreciated.--Sound.  To me, the sound quality is excellent overall.  The volume is loud enough against outside ambient noise while the open ear design allows me to hear my surroundings.  Couple with the EQ settings, my music sounds great.  With the volume down enough, I can also carry on conversations without having to remove them.--Fit.  They go with little fuss and stay on!  This allows me to enjoy my music while playing sports.  The only time they've moved out of place was when I accidentally hit them.Cons:--The Finding Headphone feature in the app.  It isn't completely useless as it will show the headphone's last active location but, the call L/R feature does not work unless they are out of the case and in use.  This lack of functionality caused me to think that I lost my headphones.  After replacing them with a different set of headphone that were on sale at the time (Soundcore V20i), they were found in my jacket pocket hanging in the closet at home lol.-Phone calls.  In louder settings, it was hard to hear my calls, even at maximum volume.  The mic, however, seemed fine as I have never gotten complaints.--Playtime (this is the main reason why I dropped a star).  I'm getting nowhere near the 7.5 hour playtime on a single charge.  I may be getting 5 hours at low to moderate volume.  For home use, this is totally fine as I'm constantly popping them on and off.  In the office, however, I would have them on all the time (because of the comfort).  Even though 15 minutes of charge will get me 2 more hours of play to get me through the rest of my work day, I opt to use the Soundcore V20i that I bought when I thought these were lost.  Although not as comfortable with glasses on, they last my entire work day.--Quality control.  This is more of a nit-pick, but the button on the right earpiece is more sunken in than the one on the left almost eliminating haptic feedback.  I can't tell when it's pressed.  This makes using it challenging enough to discourage me from using it.  I mainly use it to increase the volume but will use the phone instead (when it's with me).Overall, these are great headphones and I would highly recommend them.  For the price, they are hard to beat.

product: Baseus Bass BC1 Open Ear Earbuds Clip-On Headphones
review_text: I love these! I have the BP1 Pro which are good, but they don't stay put when I'm active, so I'm constantly having to adjust them. The BC1 clip on headphones solves this problem completely. Since they're open ear, they aren't noise-cancelling, but in return you get incredible comfort (nothing sticking in your ear canal) and most importantly, they don't fall out or move around. This design is genius. The sound is different, but I actually prefer it. There's a place for noise-cancelling earbuds (mowing the lawn), but the greater comfort far outweighs the benefit of noise cancellation in most situations. The sound itself is more natural and comfortable for TV viewing and other long listening situations, no ear fatigue. I've had zero issues with them so far, they are definitely my new favorite earbuds. For noise cancellation earbuds, I do prefer my Anker Soundcore2 over my BC1 Pro, though.

product: Baseus Bass BC1 Open Ear Earbuds Clip-On Headphones
review_text: Good sound, comfortable, good battery time, but the left earpiece mostly cuts out after a couple miles. Cleaned and charged, same issue on next run. I do sweat a lot, so maybe it's just me, but right now returning for a replacement.  If it would just completely cut out would actually be better, but it just starts sporadically connecting for a second and cuts out, so it's pretty annoying.

product: Baseus Bass BC1 Open Ear Earbuds Clip-On Headphones
review_text: i got this one prime day deal, which was mid $20. my airpods that i leave at work were dying and i thought why not give this a try at $25s and after using it for couple of hours and doing some tweaking, i am amazed by it.out of the box, the sound was subpar. at least what i was used to from airpods. but if you download the app and change the EQ, for me i choose Jazz, the sound is decent. again, you have to factor in the price.as far as comfort goes, it's not like you dont notice them on, but it's secure and light enough.i am giving this a 5 stars bc of price. you wont find any good looking, good build quality, decent sound headphones at this price. i think this could be at right under $50 and i would still give it a solid 4.5-5 stars.

product: Baseus Bowie MC1 Pro Open Ear Clip-On Headphones
review_text: Belum Ada Review

product: Baseus Bowie MC1 Pro Open Ear Clip-On Headphones
review_text: These open-ear headphones are fantastic! They are extremely comfortable and lightweight, and I can wear them for hours without any pressure or discomfort. The sound quality is surprisingly rich for open-ear design‚Äîclear highs, solid bass, and very natural audio. I love being able to stay aware of my surroundings while still enjoying music and podcasts. The battery life is impressive, and the call quality with the 4-mic system is excellent. They fit securely and don‚Äôt fall off even during exercise. Perfect for work, commuting, and workouts. The waterproof rating is a great bonus too. Overall, these are an amazing value and one of the best audio purchases I‚Äôve made. Highly recommended!

product: Baseus Bowie MC1 Pro Open Ear Clip-On Headphones
review_text: Was looking for earbuds that felt secure on my ears while I moved around, something I found lacking in the more traditional design. These seemed like a good-quality product at a reasonable price and I'm happy to report that I wasn't disappointed. Setup took less than a minute, and the battery's been impressive, have only charged the case once since I got it last Friday. The buds themselves are very comfortable on the ear. I've worn them sitting at my desk, walking around, and laying on my back and side while also wearing my CPAP mask. They stayed put every time. The sound quality is really impressive, particularly the bass. One thing I did notice was that sometimes a song will start playing on one bud before being picked up by the other one. Thought that was a little weird, but that might've been caused by my phone or the app I was streaming from at the time. I haven't made many calls with the headphones yet but I did demo the mic for a friend via a Whatsapp message. Listening back, both she and I found it to be a bit lacking in clarity, but that might also have been an issue with my connection. Overall, I like these earbuds a lot and look forward to our travels together.

product: Baseus Inspire XH1 Adaptive Active Noise Cancelling Headphones
review_text: I‚Äôve been using these headphones almost every day for a week and I‚Äôm honestly really impressed. The sound quality is rich, clear, and perfectly balanced for both music and movies. The noise cancelling works great and really helps me focus when I‚Äôm working or traveling. They‚Äôre super comfortable too ‚Äî the ear pads are soft and don‚Äôt get hot even after hours of use. The battery life is amazing; I only need to charge them once a week. The build feels solid and the design looks very clean and premium. Overall, these headphones are a fantastic value for the price and I‚Äôd definitely recommend them to anyone looking for great sound and comfort!

product: Baseus Inspire XH1 Adaptive Active Noise Cancelling Headphones
review_text: I recently got the Baseus Inspire XH1 Adaptive Active Noise Cancelling Headphones in Cosmic Black, and I must say, they have exceeded my expectations! The sound quality is simply phenomenal, thanks to Sound by Bose and Dolby Spatial Audio. It's like being enveloped in a 360¬∞ soundscape, making my music and podcasts come alive. The noise cancellation is impressive, blocking out almost all surrounding noise, which is perfect for my noisy office environment. What I love most is how comfortable they are; I can wear them for hours without any discomfort. The battery life is outstanding, lasting me several days without needing a charge. Also, the Bluetooth connection is quick and super stable. For the price, these headphones outperform even more expensive brands, making them a fantastic investment.

product: Baseus Inspire XH1 Adaptive Active Noise Cancelling Headphones
review_text: These headphones punch above their price! Please, be advised that to get the most out of these headphones you have to do 4 things out of the box: (1) charge it full, (2) download the app, which is awesome, and connect the headphones to the bluetooth source, (3) update the headphones‚Äô firmware, (4) go to the Soundfit feature and follow the instructions step by step. Soundfit actually adjusts the headphone sound to the sound frequencies as you hear then! Once Soundfit works its magic, test the headphones to your favorite music or movie. To my ears, they sound awesome! If you have android equipment, turn on the LDAC to get cd quality sound. The controls are physical and easy to use and can be adjusted via the app, which also allows you to equalize the sound to your liking or choose between the Sound by Bose (my favorite setting), Dolby or extra Bass, or any other of the aound presets.Wireless connectivity is great and I had no issues with calls. They are comfortable and fit alright to my head. They seem well built and are heavy compared to good headphones like the $30 Tozo HT2. As fir durability, time will tell. For the Black Friday price of $99.99 that includes a storage case (that by itself would sell for $10-$20) and a free gift, these headphones are a no brainer buy!

product: Baseus Inspire XH1 Adaptive Active Noise Cancelling Headphones
review_text: I think it's important to mention I have an IOS phone(apple) and a windows laptop. I wish more people mentioned this in their reviews more often to compare compatibility. I think this set would work best for an Android device, imo.My first set stopped working on the second day I used them, they were gimmicked, so Amazon did a quick replacement for me. The new pair worked better.Pros: amazing quality soundComfortableComes with a nice caseThey're lightweightPrice worth getting vs name brandsGreat battery life (headphones) *see consCons: they suddenly disconnect at random sometimes, and then i have to reconnect to my BT device. (Not sure if it's a power saver mode for the headphones)The battery life seems great on the headphones, but after downloading the baseus app, I've noticed the battery on my phone has been draining a lot faster than usual.The noise cancelling is a bit better indoors, but outdoors, it does not cancel noise at all.Not even for phone calls.(See pic for reference) when hanging around the neck the ear pieces stick outwards instead of inwards. To get them the right way you have to flip them where the Left earpiece sits on your right shoulder and Right on left shoulder.

product: Baseus Inspire XH1 Adaptive Active Noise Cancelling Headphones
review_text: The Baseus Inspire XH1 headphones are impressive on every level. The adaptive active noise cancelling is excellent and adjusts in real time, blocking out background noise effortlessly. The ‚ÄúSound by Bose‚Äù tuning and Dolby Audio give the headphones a rich, detailed, and immersive sound that feels truly premium. Bass, mids, and highs are perfectly balanced. The build quality feels solid, the fit is comfortable for long listening sessions, and the 100-hour playtime is insane ‚Äî I barely need to charge them. For this price, these headphones offer unbelievable value. Highly recommend!

product: Baseus Inspire XH1 Adaptive Active Noise Cancelling Headphones
review_text: I'm normally an ear bud user. With earbuds I was getting tired of the fear of them falling out on the plane if I fall asleep. I saw these  with sound by Bose and was interested. These a feature heavy for the price. Dolby audio/ spatial audio, transparency mode and noise cancelling.  Long battery life. Dual connect. LDAC support. I think you can get any kind of sound you like out of these. Clear vocals, bass heavy, balanced, etc. Used on a 5hr plane ride and noise cancellation blocked out airplane noise and loud conversations that were being had on the row behind me. Transparency mode made it to were I could hear the announcements clearly without taking the headphones off. The app is easy to use to control and change settings on the headphones. The physical buttons are easy to find. The headphones fit me well with absolutely no discomfort while wearing them. Good build quality. 10hrs of use with noise cancellation and transparency mode and it was only on 80% battery. Playing at full volume there is no distortion in the sound. I will probably use these solely for travel and commuting. I tried a different set of headphones from baseus, the Bowie MH1. The Bowie MH1 didn't perform as good as the InSpire XH1. I Could tell the sound quality in the XH1 was clearly superior to the Bowie MH1 instantly. But for their price they both were good. For $150 these are really good.

product: Baseus Eli 2i Fit Open-Ear Headphones
review_text: These are actually surprisingly nice. To be clear, I ordered them because they were cheap and it's nice to have a set in my car for when I'm stuck waiting at a doctors appointment or something. When I ordered them I did not notice they were "open ear" fit. Unlike most headphones of this type they do not actually have a rubber earbud tip that goes in your ear. These are actually just a speaker that sits over your ear. At first this struck me as a cheap design meant to cut costs but this is actually surprisingly pleasant. I feel they are more comfortable. The ear buds that go in my ear can be irritating after wearing them a while. These you almost forget your wearing. I like that they do not completely block out other sounds around you so can hear whats going on around you. Now you might say well but I don't want to hear all the noise around me I want to hear what I'm listening too! Because the speakers are physically over your ear they do block outside sounds notably just not as completely as say a conventional earbud does. I can still hear when someone calls my name or when the alarm on my cook timer goes off but outside sounds are not so much such that  I find it disruptive to what I am listening to. I also love the Bluetooth connection reliability! I'm not sure what the honest range is because I've worn these around the house while my phone was left on the charger and never had the connection break up. I've tested it at least 20-30 feet through walls in other rooms. That's pretty good by my experience with cheap earbuds. The only thing I do not like is the charge indicator on the base unit. It's just a single LED that blinks. There is no percentage bar or battery life indicator. It could be nearly dead or mostly charged I have no idea. This is particularly bad as the batteries for the base are kind of small and it has left me with dead headphones and a dead base that wasn't charging them unknown to me. I also kind of hate the case. It's kind of oval shaped and the top half has a ridge you can grip onto to open the lid but the lower half is curved and smooth leaving you nothing to grip onto. It's unnecessarily difficult and annoying to open and has caused me to drop it several times. For the money I think they are great. They fit well, they sound good, they are cheap, reliable. They represent a great value and I have bought a few pairs just to wear around the house while I'm doing chores or take to work.EDIT: So there is one more thing I want to add to these. I live in a colder climate and typically when I have to shovel snow I like to put in earbuds on so I can listen to something while I work. The problem is I also have to wear a hat that covers my ears to keep warm. Because the elastic puts pressure on the earbuds the classical style earbud gets jammed into my ear canal and is very uncomfortable borderline painful. I either have to take the earbuds out or wear my hat so it doesn't cover my ears which is at best uncomfortably cold and at worst leaves me vulnerable to frostbite, no joke or exaggeration there. These earbuds that just have speakers over the ear and do not actually go into the ear canal can be comfortably worn with a winter hat fully covering my ear. This is a HUGE benefit for poor souls like me who have to work outside in cold climates. Again this seemed like a cheap design at first but I'm increasingly finding I actually like it a lot better than the classic earbud design.

product: Baseus Eli 2i Fit Open-Ear Headphones
review_text: One of the best over the ear phones. It delivers strong bass clarity while helping you maintain awareness around you as you could also hear surrounding noise of your environment. Being through the rain with it and still works great.Unlike the others the Baseus elite 2i open ear headphones doesn't hurt your ears after extended use, I could wear it for extended periods without feeling discomfort on or around my earsIt has exceptionally strong battery life and call clarity is one of the best.  It is a good buy I will definitely buy again.

product: Baseus Eli 2i Fit Open-Ear Headphones
review_text: Got mine today. Some quick observations‚Ä¢ Difficult to open the charging case. Frustrating to open. I had to use my fingernail to pry it open. Fix by affixing tape to the inside bottom half of the case and folding it over it itself outside the case creating a full tab‚Ä¢ No official app supportfor the Eli 2i fit (Android, ios)  No way to customize touch‚Ä¢ No multipoint‚Ä¢ Sound is good but goes bad at higher volume. Doesn't sound as clear as the Anker v20i‚Ä¢ No neck cord as seen in the review images‚Ä¢ Pairs quickly to the last connected device‚Ä¢ Fit is comfortable even in bed

product: Baseus Eli 2i Fit Open-Ear Headphones
review_text: I've had mixed experiences with Baseus earphones before; I usually love them but find them to be less durable than I'd like.In this case, knock on wood, not only have I found the sound good and the battery life excellent, they've held up very well to extended use in sweaty conditions. Unlike earbuds that get inserted into the ear, I'm a lot less likely to wind up fostering an ear infection or winding up with part of an earbud stuck in my ear.These are also very comfortable. Eventually, I do need to adjust them, but I can forget I'm wearing them for an hour or more. They're very light.I love that they're USBC and charge with the same charger as my other devices. The case has additional battery that adds an extra couple of sessions of charging in reserve.If there's one thing I'd change, I find it hard to open the charging case sometimes. This isn't a big design issue, but it could use a slightly larger lip for people with short nails to use to open the case.

product: Baseus Eli 2i Fit Open-Ear Headphones
review_text: These are fine. Decent sound and battery life, especially for the price (under $20).  However, with that lower price comes some pretty noticeable cons. The plastic feels cheap. The new case is difficult to grip to open.  Sound while decently loud and balanced has no app you can use to change the sound profile... Pretty much in every area this is a downgrade from the earlier model (Eli sport 1).  If you're okay with those faults these are a good little set of over the ear earbuds, especially for the price.

product: Baseus Eli 2i Fit Open-Ear Headphones
review_text: These headphones are very affordable and work really well. The sound quality is clear, they are comfortable to wear, and the open-ear design is convenient for daily use. For this price, they are definitely worth it!

product: Baseus Eli 2i Fit Open-Ear Headphones
review_text: Very easy to pair to my phone and iPad. I bought mainly for listening to audiobooks and podcasts, but I was just listening to Christmas music and they sound great!. Super comfortable and they are not so loud as to disturb those around me. Excellent buy for the price I paid.

product: Baseus Eli 2i Fit Open-Ear Headphones
review_text: New model. No App support or adjustments yet. Works well. Comfortable. Good sound for open ear buds. Good deal on sale. Have had good luck with other Baseus headphones.

product: Bose QuietComfort Headphones
review_text: First, let may say that I bought them during Prime Days, when they were only $199.99, which was a discount of $150!  So, they are an incredible value.I own many pair of headphones, including AirPod Max, Sonos Ace, Bose QC 45, and the Sony XM5‚Äôs. I also owned and sold the QuietComfort Ultra, which are way overpriced, and the main selling point (their spatial sound or whatever they call it) is a joke.  I don‚Äôt think it enhances the sound at all. In fact, music has a hollow quality when using it.  Additionally, I prefer the QuietComfort‚Äôs buttons to the Ultra‚Äôs touch controls, which seemed awkward.  Additionally, the Ultra utilize a 35mm driver, while the QuietComfort use a 40mm driver.  While the Ultra may be more efficient, I think the low end frequencies suffer compared to the QuietComfort.  The Bose QuietComfort are quickly becoming my favorite.  The sound quality is second to none.  It is noticeably better than the QC 45. The bass is definitely deeper and punchier. The highs and mids are also discernibly better. The highs are brighter and more crisp, though the highs are never harsh on my ears.  The 45‚Äôs require a lot of equalizer use (+6, 0, -3), while the QuietComfort still require some tinkering, they require a lot less of it to achieve optimum sound (+1, +2, +1).  Even at -3 on the EQ for the highs on the 45‚Äôs, the higher frequencies feel like they need to be reined in.  Indeed, the QuietComfort just sound more refined.  The noise cancelling has also improved, though I would say both the Sony XM5‚Äôs and the Sonos Aces are a touch better at cancelling most noise.  I run an air purifier at arm‚Äôs length away from my chair, and a window a/c to supplement the central air, which is directly behind my head.  With the XM5‚Äôs I can completely eliminate the noise from both while they‚Äôre simultaneously running.  With the new QuietComfort I can just barely detect the a/c, while with the 45‚Äôs I can easily pick up the a/c.  The difference here between the Sonys and the new QuietComfort is marginal at best. I should mention that part of Bose‚Äôs way to cancel noise is to pump low-volume white noise into the headphones, which seems counterintuitive, but I don‚Äôt mind it.  Others may mind it, however.  The QuietComfort are the most-comfortable to wear, though they are no different than the 45‚Äôs in that regard.  They are extremely lightweight (though sturdy), and clamp down perfectly tight.  I can shake my head back and forth without them shifting, yet they‚Äôre not so tight as to prevent wearing them for an extended period of time.  I don‚Äôt work out, but I would imagine they‚Äôd maintain their fit during exercise. They also offer multi-point connectivity, and they (and the 45‚Äôs) are the only two pair to switch seamlessly between my LG TV and my iPhone.  The XM5‚Äôs require using the app, the Sonos don‚Äôt do it as easily as advertised while using my tv for some reason and the AirPods Max don‚Äôt even offer multipoint functionality.  Bose states that you get 24 hour battery life on a full charge, and I‚Äôve found that to be accurate.  While that‚Äôs less than the Sonos and Sony‚Äôs battery life (30 hours), it‚Äôs more than the Apple‚Äôs (20 hour).  I have found the battery life to be  sufficient.  If you own a pair of 45‚Äôs and are looking for an upgrade, then I would say there‚Äôs not quite enough of a performance gap to justify the $349 price tag, however, if you catch them on sale for $199 like I did, then I would definitely recommend upgrading.  If you‚Äôre looking for your first pair, then I would definitely recommend the QuietComfort over all the others I mentioned, even at $349.  I hope that helps.  Happy Listening!

product: Bose QuietComfort Headphones
review_text: I bought the ultras on the black friday sale last week and while the noise cancellation was amazing, I felt a bit overwhelmed by all the features in the app, the touch volume control on the side, the heavy headset, etc. I decided to try these out and I‚Äôm SO glad I did. Personally I find these way more comfortable on my head and I think they‚Äôre a bit lighter. The noise cancellation is still great - the ultras maybe block out 5% more but have that hissing NC noise way louder which I didn‚Äôt like. This still blocks out sound really well and plenty enough for me. I‚Äôm not on flights or in loud places that often so for me it‚Äôs more about blocking out background noise at home which it does excellently. If you don‚Äôt need the spatial audio, immersion modes, extreme NC, and high tech features of the ultra I honestly would go with these. They were much cheaper (got these on cyber monday sale and were nearly $150 less than the ultras) and I personally prefer them. Love the simple and user friendly controls too. I‚Äôm a millennial and good with tech, but sometimes it‚Äôs too much and too gimmicky. These are great though and you can really tell a difference between the aware and quiet modes. It‚Äôs very nice having that option. I hope they last for years to come!

product: Bose Ultra Open Earbuds
review_text: Usually I say they are good for what it‚Äôs worth.  In this case, for what I paid for them, they are not worth it.Pro‚Äôs:  the ear clip/cuff design is different and good, the fit is pretty secure and won‚Äôt fall off, comfortable, immersive sound is a plus, turning off the immersive sound and they last  longer between charges.  When running I hardly noticed I had them on my ears.  The sound was good when I was running.  I noticed as I was running that the music got louder.  I think it was because they settled onto my ear lobes and also I turned the automatic volume control.Cons: too expensive, can‚Äôt adjust to being closer to ear canal, left me wanting and expecting more from the ear cuff buds.  They seem limited when turning them up to 7 or 8 on the flat setting.  Should be priced around the sound core and shokz open fit buds price, maybe even pricing them lower like $125-$150 on the high end.  For $300 they should have wireless charging, multi point connectivity.  Most of all a larger and louder volume level.  I‚Äôm returning them.  My aftershockz aeropex bone conduction headphones do a better job and lasts my whole 10 hour workday without needing to be charged.Maybe another software update with automatic multipoint switching, adjust the eq curve to have more low end and not cap the bass when playing at a higher volume, and drop the price and they would an awesome product.Update 3/12/2024So I returned my first pair of ultra earbuds, and got a set of Shokz open fit earbuds.  I tried those on for some time and really like how they performed overall.  But somehow I started to miss the bose earbuds, and wanted to compare how they went up against the Shokz offering.  The price is still steep, but I had an amazon gift card balance of $157 so I went ahead and bought the Bose to do the comparison.The fit was excellent as before, the sound is excellent, I registered them to get the two year nose warranty as I can see these being replaced sometime in September the future.  The Shokz are really good and probably rank them as one of the best hook buds in the market.  For me and my ears, the Bose and the Shokz are an excellent buy.  They both are light and fitment is excellent, the sound is superb, the call quality I give to Shokz, the update happened to both and somehow the call quality on the bose really improved.  I still prefer the physical button over the touch sensitive approach that Shokz went with.  I still like the Bose ear cuff design vs the earhook.  So which do I prefer.  Running and exercising-Bose without a doubt, mountain biking and any sport with a lot of wind noise-Shokz hands down.3/19/2024I started noticing the Bose ultra open buds starting to lose connection when putting them on.  The right ear would get the connected prompts, but the left would not connect and when it does connect, it loses drops connection a couple of time more than connects and syncs up with the right ear.  I‚Äôm going to request for a replacement pair.  Overall, these are excellent buys if you have a gift card balance to buy down these buds.  The Shokz were on sale so I returned my black pair and got the white pair.  I had some Amazon credits and used those credits to buy the Shokz at much lower price.3/29/2024Bose pushed an update to the open ultras (version 1.10.4).  The audio sounded clearer, the connection issue seems to have been resolved, I noticed while doing yard work that my Bose lasted approximately 5 hours on the immersion setting.  No multipoint connectivity like the Shokz open fits have.  Also,  I saw that Bose released a wireless charging case on their website for $50.  I decided to not get the wireless charging case because I was already used to the usb-c plug approach.

product: Bose Ultra Open Earbuds
review_text: i've bought and tried so many of these types of open style earbuds.  the anker c40s, shokz openfit 2, powerbeats pro 2 (not open but similar style), edifier lolliclip, soundpeats pealclip pro, and the list goes on.  I watched reviews and demo'd many others.  I've stayed away from the Bose because of reviews saying they were overpriced or because competitors were just as good (or close to as good).  i wish i tried these for myself a year ago, because i can now say this position is completely wrong.  none of the options sound anywhere close to as good as the Bose. if sound quality is your top priority then don't get convinced into buying an inferior product for a gimmicky feature.the bose have nailed the open sound - it's a wide and dynamic sound stage vs. others that sound either too shrill, hollow, or missing low end.  I'm surprised at how well these manage bass response especially in quiet environments - they sound exactly how you'd expect Bose to sound.  It seems like the biggest criticisms these get are the price, which is understandable, and phone call mic quality.  i was able to get these on sale, and if you're anywhere in the ballpark on price vs. alternatives, i would pay the premium and get these.  The best low cost alternative I tried are the Soundpeats pearl clips - great value for the money.  For call quality, it wasn't a huge priority for me.  The few calls I've made worked fine without complaints.Overall, here are my Pros:+ Best sound quality by far in this category - smooth, responsive, and WIDE sound stage+ Extremely comfortable - I can wear these all day and not notice+ Value - more expensive than the value segment, but also not exceedingly expensive esp. when on sale.  Well worth the additional money.+ Styling - these have more of a sporty/tech look than the others.  To me, they look less like earings and more like buds.  I never loved the look of the earing style.+ App - clean app with all the features I actually needCons- Call quality?  Not yet for me and also not a huge priority, but I'll trust what others have said- Is there a v2 in the works?  it seems like every other brand has released 2-3 updated versions in the time Bose released these.  I was holding out to see if Bose would release a v2, but that hasn't happened and they're so far ahead of competitors I'm not sure they even need to.  Would be nice to maybe have better water and/or dust resistance...

product: Bose QuietComfort Earbuds II
review_text: Very comfortable, great sound, love how I can switch between 'noise cancellation' to remove all outside sound, or a 'pass through' setting so that I can hear what's going on around me.

product: Bose QuietComfort Earbuds II
review_text: Love this, I have iPods and these are my go to over the iPods. You can change the the bass, treble, and sounds in the app on your phone or tablet. The sound is amazing and I often fall asleep with them in. They also last 6 to 8 hours when wearing them!

product: Bose QuietComfort Earbuds II
review_text: They work great. Did not come with the "Fit Kit".

product: Bose QuietComfort Earbuds II
review_text: Lets start with sound quality. Sound quality is very good. As the volume goes up, the quality stays the same.Battery life. I will say the battery life is good. My volume stays around 30% with active noise cancelling on and I get 6 hours per charge.A. N.C. ( active noise cancelling ). ANC is very good. I use it all the time at work on the transparency mode. Helps loud noise from being so rough on my ears but if it's really loud I will hear it pop in the buds. On quite mode is something even today I have a hard time adjusting to. It cuts out so much noise that when I take the buds out my ears, my brain has to adjust back to all the back ground noise again.Stability connections. Connecting Bluetooth when I first got the buds was easy but now is a whole new story. I have had one bud drop out of connection and the reconnect 3-5 minutes later. I have even had it were the buds was not insync with the sound.Comfort. I will say for myself I can wear the buds for a long period of time. The hardest part for me now is getting that tone in my ear to let me know it's a good fit in my ear. I have slept several times with them in my ears.App. This is where I think my biggest problem is with these buds. The app has a hand full of options and nothing impressive. You use the app to update the buds but the last update I believe gave me all my problems.So I say yes these are very good buds but nothing to go break the bank to get.

product: Bose QuietComfort Earbuds II
review_text: I bought some for myself about a year ago and bought these for my fianc√© for his birthday. He absolutely loves them! He started listening to some of his favorite songs and said, ‚ÄúHave I even been listening to music this whole time?‚Äù It was like discovering music for the first time for him. Bose will always be my favorite for listening to music and their active noise cancelling is unbeatable.

product: Bose QuietComfort Earbuds II
review_text: Oh good lord, I lost my favorite earbuds and had to use these in a pinch, and they are somehow worse than I remember. They‚Äôre way too expensive for the quality, they‚Äôre glitchy and the sound just wavers randomly like 2-5 times a minute - my $35 Tozo earbuds hold a charge longer. Buy those instead if you want noise canceling earbuds!

product: Bose QuietComfort Earbuds II

product: Bose QuietComfort Bluetooth Headphones
review_text: First, let may say that I bought them during Prime Days, when they were only $199.99, which was a discount of $150!  So, they are an incredible value.I own many pair of headphones, including AirPod Max, Sonos Ace, Bose QC 45, and the Sony XM5‚Äôs. I also owned and sold the QuietComfort Ultra, which are way overpriced, and the main selling point (their spatial sound or whatever they call it) is a joke.  I don‚Äôt think it enhances the sound at all. In fact, music has a hollow quality when using it.  Additionally, I prefer the QuietComfort‚Äôs buttons to the Ultra‚Äôs touch controls, which seemed awkward.  Additionally, the Ultra utilize a 35mm driver, while the QuietComfort use a 40mm driver.  While the Ultra may be more efficient, I think the low end frequencies suffer compared to the QuietComfort.  The Bose QuietComfort are quickly becoming my favorite.  The sound quality is second to none.  It is noticeably better than the QC 45. The bass is definitely deeper and punchier. The highs and mids are also discernibly better. The highs are brighter and more crisp, though the highs are never harsh on my ears.  The 45‚Äôs require a lot of equalizer use (+6, 0, -3), while the QuietComfort still require some tinkering, they require a lot less of it to achieve optimum sound (+1, +2, +1).  Even at -3 on the EQ for the highs on the 45‚Äôs, the higher frequencies feel like they need to be reined in.  Indeed, the QuietComfort just sound more refined.  The noise cancelling has also improved, though I would say both the Sony XM5‚Äôs and the Sonos Aces are a touch better at cancelling most noise.  I run an air purifier at arm‚Äôs length away from my chair, and a window a/c to supplement the central air, which is directly behind my head.  With the XM5‚Äôs I can completely eliminate the noise from both while they‚Äôre simultaneously running.  With the new QuietComfort I can just barely detect the a/c, while with the 45‚Äôs I can easily pick up the a/c.  The difference here between the Sonys and the new QuietComfort is marginal at best. I should mention that part of Bose‚Äôs way to cancel noise is to pump low-volume white noise into the headphones, which seems counterintuitive, but I don‚Äôt mind it.  Others may mind it, however.  The QuietComfort are the most-comfortable to wear, though they are no different than the 45‚Äôs in that regard.  They are extremely lightweight (though sturdy), and clamp down perfectly tight.  I can shake my head back and forth without them shifting, yet they‚Äôre not so tight as to prevent wearing them for an extended period of time.  I don‚Äôt work out, but I would imagine they‚Äôd maintain their fit during exercise. They also offer multi-point connectivity, and they (and the 45‚Äôs) are the only two pair to switch seamlessly between my LG TV and my iPhone.  The XM5‚Äôs require using the app, the Sonos don‚Äôt do it as easily as advertised while using my tv for some reason and the AirPods Max don‚Äôt even offer multipoint functionality.  Bose states that you get 24 hour battery life on a full charge, and I‚Äôve found that to be accurate.  While that‚Äôs less than the Sonos and Sony‚Äôs battery life (30 hours), it‚Äôs more than the Apple‚Äôs (20 hour).  I have found the battery life to be  sufficient.  If you own a pair of 45‚Äôs and are looking for an upgrade, then I would say there‚Äôs not quite enough of a performance gap to justify the $349 price tag, however, if you catch them on sale for $199 like I did, then I would definitely recommend upgrading.  If you‚Äôre looking for your first pair, then I would definitely recommend the QuietComfort over all the others I mentioned, even at $349.  I hope that helps.  Happy Listening!
